respStmt.resp: Conversion to TEI based on earlier work for the ENRICH project (enrich@oucs.ox.ac.uk; http://tei.oucs.ox.ac.uk/ENRICH/)

msDesc.head: A-D ‘Codex Oxoniensis Posterior’, etc., Cornwall (and Wales?), s. x; E Penitential collection, N. E. France (?), s. ix1

physDesc.p: Two separate books (fols. 1-50, ‘Codex Oxoniensis Posterior’, and fols. 51-106) with evidence of separate earlier binding from the rustmarks on fols. 1, 50, 51, 106; bound together by 1606. The first book in turn comprised of four originally independent manuscripts: fol. i | fols. 2-25 | fols. 26-40 | fols. 41-50.

history.provenance: The additions relating to St Augustine’s, Canterbury (fols. 39v, 49v) suggest that fols. 1-50 had reached that institution by the late 11th century at the latest.

Fols. 1-50, but not certainly fol. 51-105, identifiable as BA1.129 in the 15th-century St Augustine’s library catalogue: ‘Textus Thobie cum A 2o fo et quando et In eodem Exposicio canonis dist’ 1 Ga. 3o’.
history.acquisition: Given by him in 1606 (Summary Catalogue I.93).

recordHist.source:
Summary description by Elizabeth Solopova and Matthew Holford, based on the Summary Catalogue and supplementary sources.
Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 170 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 171 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 172 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 173 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 174

listBibl.bibl: A. G. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts c.435-1600 in Oxford Libraries (Oxford, 1984), no. 102 [fols. 2-50]
Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library Oxford, III (1973), no. 28 [fols. 26-40]
S. J. P. Van Dijk, Handlist of the Latin Liturgical Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library Oxford : Vol. 1: Mass Books (typescript, 1957), p. 201 [fols. 1, 39v, 40r, 47r-40v, 90v]

ref.title: DIAMM: Digital Image Archive of Medieval Music
MLGB3: Medieval Libraries of Great Britain

history.origin: Part 1 probably all written in Cornwall (though formerly considered Welsh), 10th century, and circulating together, 10th century.
history.provenance: Perhaps at Glastonbury in the 10th century (see below).
Perhaps at Winchester in the 10th century.
At St Augustine’s, Canterbury, by the end of the eleventh century: perhaps brought there from Glastonbury by Abbot Sigeric in 980.

msItem.title: Missa propria Germani episcopi
msItem.note: (fragment)
Pr. H. Jenner, ‘The Lannaled mass of St Germanus in Bodl. MS. 572’, Journal of the Royal Institution of Cornwall 23 (1929-32), 477-92.

origin.origPlace: English, Cornwall, probably St Germans / Lanalet

msItem.title: Expositio missae ‘Dominus vobiscum’
msItem.rubric: ET QVANDO DICIT DOMINUS VOBISCVM | INCIPIT EXPOSITIO MISSAE
msItem.incipit: Saluat sacerdos populum & orat
msItem.explicit: et omnes respondent ite missa est deo gratias

msItem.title: Tobit

msItem.incipit: Cromatio et eliodrio episcopis hironimus in domino salutem. Mirari non desino
msItem.note: Jerome's prologue (Stegmüller 332).

msItem.incipit: (fol. 14v) Thobias extribu et ciuitate neptalim
msItem.note: With three Cornish glosses.

musicNotation.p: Fol. 13v: Anglo-Saxon neums over ‘ite missa est deo gratias’ (Hartzell).

history.provenance: Presumably written before the Easter table was added on fol. 40v.

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Epistula ad Probam de orando deo (ep. 130)
msItem.rubric: Incipit aepistola agustini ępiscopi ad probam [added later:] de orando deo
msItem.incipit: Augustinus seruus seruorumque christi religiossę famulę dei probę
Et petisse te et promisisse me recolens
msItem.note: CSEL 44, pp. 40-77 (collated as MS. O).

msItem.author: Caesarius of Arles (Ps.-Augustine)
msItem.title: De igne purgatorio
msItem.rubric: Incipit ępistola agustini de igne purgatorio
msItem.incipit: In lectione apostolica que nobis paulo ante recitata est
msItem.explicit: Et elimosinarum largitate possint redimere . prestante domino nostro iesu christo qui cum patre et spiritu sancto uiuis et regnas in secula seculorum amen

msItem.note: Added texts:
Antiphons, added in several hands probably at Canterbury, early twelfth century:

msItem.incipit: Dilectus hic pollet tuus sanctissimum nostrum decus
Laurenti martyr inclite . Cele terris mirifice
O uirgo mater inclicis . pręlata summis ciuibus
Augustine fidelium . Salus te deprecantium
Mildretha uirgo celebris . Potens ope miraculis

msItem.note: Forms of benediction for use at the distribution of funeral-food, at manumissions, and at the blessing of crops, each preceded by a rubric in Old English; printed Haddan and Stubbs, Councils, I.697-8; Ker, Catalogue, pp. 376-7 (Old English only). Main text and third dated by Ker to the tenth century, first two rubrics (in red ink) to the first half of the eleventh century (with query).

Key to cryptographic writing, with two Old English cryptograms, pr. Ker p. 377; dated by him to the mid-eleventh century. Both cryptograms also occur in BL Cotton Vitellius E. xviii (Winchester, s. xi med).
Easter table
Addition; covers 836-1367; perhaps written in 981 (possible faint mark in the rectangle for this year).

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 26r-39v written in insular minuscule by Bledian, fols. 36, 39v.

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials coloured in red and yellow.

history.origin:
10th century
English, Cornwall (or Wales (?)) ; additions, 10th century - early 12th century, Winchester (?) and Canterbury

msItem.note: Now blank except for runes and runic alphabet (cf. S. Gwara, Education in Wales and Cornwall (2003-4), 13 and n. 37). Erased text, perhaps a text on the Harrowing of Hell; cf. partial transcription by E. W. B. Nicholson, now pasted on fol. i.

msItem.title: De aliquibus raris fabulis
msItem.note: A Latin colloquy, with glosses in Old English, Latin, and Brittonic (Welsh and Cornish), both interlinear and embedded in the text (see S. Gwara, Education in Wales and Cornwall, passim). Text and glosses pr. from this the unique manuscript by Scott Gwara, De raris fabulis (Cambridge, 2002).
Text incomplete, breaks off 47r l. 15 in mid word ‘plane’.
msItem.textLang: Latin, Old English, Welsh and Cornish

msItem.note: Liturgical and other additions
Antiphons
msItem.incipit: Auctor salutis hominum iesu nostrum refugium
Beata uere ciuitas quam illustrat diuinitas
Compassionis gratia christi perfecta
(fol. 47v) Domine rex omnipotens libera famulum tuum
Excelsus super omnes gentes dominus & super cęlos
Fac benignissime deus cum seruo tuo misericordiam
Gratia dei per iesum christum quę te liberauit de corpore mortis
Hodie in pace fiat locus eius & in sion habitatio eius
Libera quesumus domine animam huius de locis penarum
(fol. 48r) Defensor animarum alme qui pro hominum salute de sinu patris descendisti
Dominus fons misericordię in qua cuncta lauantur contagia delictorum
Clementissime domine qui pro nostra miseria ab impiorum manibus

msItem.note: Responsories and versicles from an office for the dead, identified by van Dijk as Benedictine:
msItem.incipit: Misericordissime deus uniuerse carnis
Hiesu clementer huius miserere benignus
Ne intres in iudicium
Miserere mei domine quoniam ad te clamaui
Rogamus te dominus deus noster
Quoniam non est in morte
Ne tradas domine bestiis animas
Quoniam non est & animas
Absolue domine animas eorum
Sicque illi sunt domine digne cruciatibus
Libera me domine de morte &erna
Dies illa dies ire
Quid ego miserrimus
Nunc Christe te deprecor
msItem.note: Ottosen, Latin Office of the Dead, R 49, V 110, 151, 368; R 83, V 191; R 58, V 191 (?); R 1, V 216; R 38, V 55, 180, 159
Strophe on St. Augustine of Canterbury; added, late 11th century.
msItem.incipit: Huius regine stantis a dextris imperiali

msItem.note: Versicle of the responsory ‘Sancte dei pretiose’ in honour of St. Stephen (cantus 007575a) with an alphabetical notation for two voices; added, late 11th century.
msItem.incipit: Ut tuo propitiatus

msItem.note: ‘Benedicamus domino’ with neums; added, late 11th century.
Rhymed antiphon for a bishop; added, late 11th century.
msItem.incipit: Presul almus hodie inuitatus

msItem.note: Noted prose for the dedication; added, late 11th century.
msItem.incipit: Virginis matris annua

msItem.note: 50r-v ruled but blank.

musicNotation.p: Fols. 47r-49v: German, Anglo-Saxon, and Anglo-Norman neums (Hartzell, no. 259).

history.origin: 10th century English, Cornwall (?) additions, 11th century, England, Canterbury (St Augustine’s) or perhaps Glastonbury.

msItem.title: Canonical-penitential collection
msItem.incipit: concepto semine usque ad modum consumendi
msItem.note: In twenty-one chapters; begins imperfect; ch. 1 and part of ch. 2 missing.

Chs. 2-16 (fols. 51r-70r) comprise Excarpsus Cummeani siue Poenitentiale pseudo-Cummeani, in the order cc. 3 (= c. 2 here); 1-2 (c. 2, here c. 4, ends at section 21 ‘Qui semen dormiens...’), 4-14 (here 6-16), as pr. E. Wasserschleben, Die bussordnungen der abendländischen kirche (1851), pp. 473-5, 465-71, 475-493

Ch. 17 (fols. 70r-76v) comprises a canonical collection. Fols. 70r-73r22 (as pointed out by Asbach, Poenitentiale Remense, 57-9) are paralleled by the collection in København, Kongelike Bibliothek, Ny Kgl. Saml., 58 8°, fols. 35r-43r, also following a text of the Excarpsus. Most, but apparently not all, of the material on fols. 73r22-76v is also found in the Vetus Gallica collection (Asbach, op. cit., pp. 61-64).

msItem.rubric: TITULUS DE CANNONES QUOD PRESBYTERI IN PARROCHIIS DOMINICIS DENUNTIARE DEBENT DE CONDITIONES INLICITES QUID DEBEANT CAUERE
msItem.incipit: NON LICET KALENDAS IANURIAS NEC ULLA FAcere uel ceruulo uel strinis diabolicas obseruare
msItem.note: Council of Auxerre, 561, canons 1-27 (23-4 here reversed in order), 29-41, 43 (ed. MGH Concilia I, 179-83).

msItem.incipit: Si quis presbyter aut diaconus gulae atque ebrietate deseruiens
msItem.note: Canones Apostolorum (42-44 as numbered in PL 67.146).

msItem.incipit: Clericus cume extranea muliere non habitet
msItem.note: Statuta Ecclesiae Antiqua 27, 35, 77, 83 (PL 56.883-7)

msItem.incipit: Si quis episcopus aut presbyter non trinam mersionem
msItem.note: Canones Apostolorum (50 as numbered in PL 67.148).

msItem.incipit: Si quis ex saecularibus hanc institutionem uel communionem
msItem.note: Council of Auxerre, 561, canons 44-45 (ed. MGH Concilia I, 183).

msItem.incipit: Rogationes Idest laetanias ante ascensionem domini
msItem.note: Council of Orleans, 511, canon 27 (ed. MGH Concilia I, 8)

msItem.incipit: Placuit etiam universis fratribus ut in prima ebdomada
msItem.note: Council of Lyons (567/570), canon 6 (Collectio Vetus Gallica xxiv.6), ending at ‘decreverunt’ (MGH Concilia I, 140).

msItem.incipit: Offerre not licet ad altare praeter spicas nouas
msItem.note: Canones Apostolorum (4-5 as numbered in PL 67.141; Collectio Vetus Gallica xxvi.2-3).

msItem.incipit: (fol. 74r7-74r18) Monachis nisi abbatis sui aut permisso aut uoluntate ad alterum
Monachi etiam uagantes ad officium clericatus
Monasterium nouum nisi aut permittente episcopo
msItem.note: Canon. Agatensis 19 (Vetus gallica xlvi.2), first three paragraphs, in order 3, 2, 1.

msItem.incipit: Abbatis prohumilitate religionis in episcoborum potestate
msItem.note: Council of Orleans, 511, canon 19 (ed. MGH Concilia I, 7), Vetus gallica xlvi.3.

msItem.incipit: Unde necesse est ut iam tertia uel quarta generatio fidelium licenter sibi iungi debeant. Mulieres consuetam menstruatam patitur
msItem.note: Extract from Gregory-Augustine, Libellus responsionum, cc. v (MGH Epp. 2, p. 335 l. 10-11) and viii (ibid. p. 339 ll. 11-14, 27-30.

msItem.incipit: Monacho uti orario in monasterio uel
msItem.note: Canon. Agatensis (506) 18; Vetus Gallica xlvi.4).

msItem.incipit: De abbatibus uero uel monachis (fol. 75r) ltare conueniat ut quicquid cannones
msItem.note: c. 15 of the Council of Autun under Leodegar (MGH Concilia I.221); Vetus Gallica xlvi.12.

msItem.incipit: Si quis in monasterio nutritus
msItem.note: Collectio Hibernensis xlii.14b; Vetus Gallica xlvi.14.

msItem.incipit: Si quis susciperit monachum alterius
msItem.note: Collectio Hibernensis xxxix.10a, 11, 10b; Vetus Gallica xlvi.15-17.

msItem.incipit: Statuimus atque decernimus ut nullus monachum alterius
msItem.note: Council of Autun under Leodegar, paragraph preceding c. 15 (MGH Concilia I.221); Vetus Gallica xlvi.11

msItem.incipit: Clerici sine commendaticiis epistolis
msItem.note: Canon. Agatensis (506) 38, first part; Vetus Gallica xlvi.13

msItem.incipit: Puer usque ad xv annos
msItem.note: Theodore of Tarsus, Iudicia, version ‘U’ (‘discipulus Umbrensis’), r,2,12.37, first part; 2,14.13; 2,14.5; Vetus Gallica xlvi.19-21

msItem.incipit: GREGRORIUS AIT tam piscis in terra
msItem.note: Collectio Hibernensis xxxix.4a-c; Vetus Gallica xlvi.22-24.

msItem.incipit: Alibi scriptum est. Quicquid monasterio de rebus saecularis superabundet
msItem.note: Collectio Hibernensis xxxix.5 (attrib. Gildas).

msItem.incipit: Sanctae moniales quamlibet una eorum
msItem.note: Conc. Agatensis (506) c. 19; Vetus Gallica xlvii.3

msItem.incipit: Episcopus presbyter aut diaconus uel clerici horis (?) praeteritis
msItem.note: Concilium Epaonense (517), c. 20; Vetus Gallica xlvii.4

msItem.incipit: Ad faciendas missas qui ingressi fuerint
msItem.note: Concilium Epaonense (517), c. 38 (MGH Conc. I. 28); = Vetus Gallica xlvii.5; here without first sentence.

msItem.incipit: ANASTASIUS DIXIT Cottidie martyres fiunt martyr enim testis interpretatur
msItem.note: Short extract from Caesarius of Arles, Serm. 47 (Ps.-Augustine, Serm. 232)
Ch. 18 (fols. 76v-80r)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Hormisdas (Caesarius of Arles)
msItem.title: Canon ‘Ecce manifestissme’
msItem.note: (Jaffé, Regesta Pontificum †868)
msItem.rubric: INCIPIT EPISTOLA ORMISDI PAPE PER UNIUERSIS PROUINCIIS
msItem.incipit: Si quis diaconus aut presbyter post acceptam benedictionem leuiticam
(fol. 77r) Ecce manifestissime constat quia secundum titulis antiquorum patrum
msItem.note: Pr. Concilia Galliae a. 511 - a. 695, CCSL 148A (1963), 90-6, ll. 106-272, here preceded by canon 22 of the Council of Orange (441).; cf. Vetus Gallica xvi.18a-18ab.
Ch. 19 (fols. 80r-v)
msItem.incipit: Biduanas xij cum ciij psalterios
msItem.explicit: Tu qui haec paenitentiale legis haec retene & hora
msItem.note: Followed by a note on the Penitential Psalms
Ch. 20 (fols. 80v-82r)
msItem.author: Ps.-Jerome
msItem.title: Inquisitio de paenitentia
msItem.rubric: ITEM DOMNI HIERONIMI PRESBITERI DE PAENITENTIA
msItem.incipit: Triduanas xij cum iij psalterios impletos
msItem.note: Lambert no. 611 (different explicit); partly as pr. Wasserschleben, Bussordnungen , pp. 229-30 (as c. 10-12 of Ps.-Bede, Penitential).
Ch. 21 (fols. 82r-83r)
msItem.rubric: DE DIUITE UEL POtenTE QUOMODO SIBI REDEMAT DE CRIMINALIBVS CULPIS
msItem.incipit: Recurrat ad euangelium & imitatur Zacheo
msItem.note: Poenitentiale Remense: extract from c. 2 (ed. Wasserschleben, Die bussordnungen der abendländischen kirche, pp. 499-500; ed. Asbach, Poenitentiael Remense, p. 12-14).

msItem.title: Treatise on penitance
msItem.note: Eight sections; unidentified. The first two sections also in Bamberg, Staatsbibl., Can. 2 (A. I. 35), fol. 31v (pr. V. Krause in Neues Archiv der Gesellschaft für ältere deutsche Geschichtskunde 17 (1892), 324-5), followed by canons of the council of Mainz (852). The opening incipit (‘Septem igitur annorum...’) also in Paris, BnF, Latin 2998, fol. 83; Vienna, ONB, lat. 752, fol. 53v.

msItem.rubric: INCIPIT ORDO NUMERUM ANNORUM INDICTA PAENITENTIA PER CONSILIUM SACERDOTIS
msItem.incipit: (fol. 83v) Septem igitur annorum tempore debes habere paenitentiam indictam
Ut quando tibi possibilitas fuerit pomatam uel cerusiam tenuem bibas
Quandocumque iungis te ad episcopis & si te illi caritatis causa rogauerint
Si igitur frater in caritate superuenerit & erogauerit
msItem.explicit: excepto carne tantum manduca & bibe cum eo

msItem.incipit: Si autem homo saecularis ad te uenerit
Ne anima ieiuna caelestis medici ne longo tempore deperiat iubemus ut ad alteram pascham ad sacri altaris communionem accedas
msItem.explicit: accedere tibi iubemus ad corpus christi

msItem.rubric: DE HORA AUTEM MANDUCANDI DICTURI SUMUS
msItem.incipit: Quod sexta hora semper manducis nisi quarta & sexta feria

msItem.rubric: DE INFIRMO QUI TOTUM PAENITERE NON POTEST CONSILIUM DICIMUS
msItem.incipit: Si quis autem de his quae scripsimus contra tuam infirmitatem

msItem.author: Gregory the Great
Augustine of Canterbury
msItem.title: Libellus responsionum
msItem.note: (c. 9 only)
msItem.rubric: INTERROGATIO BEATI AGUSTINI EPISCOPI AD GREGORIUM PAPE URBIS ROME
msItem.incipit: Si post inlusionem quae per somnium solet accedere
msItem.note: CPL 1327

msItem.author: Ecgberht of York
msItem.title: Poenitentiale
msItem.note: (prologue only)
msItem.incipit: Institutio illa sancta que fiebat indiebus patrum nostrorum
msItem.note: CPL 1887; Haddan and Stubbs, Councils and Ecclesiatical Documents III.416-418.

Collects, secrets, and postcommunions for two masses (the second with the marginal heading ‘xxv’); the first five texts only are associated in several sources with the 21st and 22nd Sundays after Trinity.

msItem.incipit: Delicta nostra quibus aduersa dominantur
Caelestim nobis prebeant haec misteria
Ut sacris domine reddamur digni muneribus
Familiam tuam quesumus domine continua pietate custodi
Suscipe domini propiciatus hostias quibus
Purificent nos semper et muniant

msItem.author: Pirmin
msItem.title: De singulis libris canonicis scarapsus
msItem.incipit: Fratres karissimi spiritus sanctus per prophetam sacerdotes
msItem.note: Ends imperfect at end of c. 24 (ed. Hauswald, MGH, p. 89, = PL 89, 1043A)

handDesc.handNote: fols. 51r-86r: Caroline minuscule; rubrics in uncial.
fols. 86r-90r, 91r-106v: seemingly one other scribe, Caroline minuscule with frequent ‘cc’ form of a.
fol. 90v: a third hand, Caroline minuscule with insular form of g and ‘open’ a alongside the regular Carolingian form.

history.provenance: Dating and localization: see Bischoff, Katalog, no. 3787
